{{Template:Infobox military gear | name = Uniforms of the Italian Armed Forces | image = [[File:Italian army (Nouveaau Larousse,c. 1900) DSCN2853.jpg|right|350x410px|Italian army (Nouveaau Larousse,c. 1900) DSCN2853]] | alt =Italian Armed Forces' uniforms in the XIX Century | caption = Italian Armed Forces' uniforms in the XIX Century | image_size = | origin = [[Italy]] | description = Uniforms of the Italian Armed Forces in the 19th Century | type = [[Military Uniforms]] | service = 1861 - present | used_by = [[Marina Militare|Marina Militare (Navy)]]
[[Italian Army|Esercito Italiano (Army)]]
[[Italian Air Force|Aeronautica Militare (Air Force)]]
[[Carabinieri|Arma dei Carabinieri (Gendarmerie)]] }} The '''Uniforms of the Italian Armed Forces''' are categorized by the four different branches of the Italian military: the [[Italian Army]], the [[Italian Navy]], the [[Italian Air Force]] and the [[Carabinieri|Carabinieri Corps]].{{Cite web|url=https://armedforces.eu/Italy|title=Italy-Army, Navy, Air Force and Carabinieri|last=|first=|date=|website=ArmedForces|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-24}} Each one of these [[Military|armed forces]] and their subsections have their own [[Uniform|uniforms]]. The style of these historical uniforms can be traced back to the [[Royal Sardinian Army]] in the mid-19th Century, which was the predecessor of the current Italian Armed Forces.{{cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/Equipment/Militaria/Uniforms/Pagine/Uniformi-Storiche.aspx|title=Historical uniforms|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=1 October 2018}} ==History== The uniforms of the Italian Armed Forces, at first, had symbolic meanings and, later on, became more function and grades based. The [[Expedition of the Thousand|Spedizione dei Mille]] was an event during the war for [[Risorgimento]] (Italian Unification), where [[Giuseppe Garibaldi|Giuseppe Garibaldi's]] thousand volunteer troops helped him liberate the [[Kingdom of the Two Sicilies]]. All of the troops wore red shirts, following the example of Garibaldi's Italian Legion that had fought in the [[Uruguayan Civil War|Guerra Grande]] in South America. This earned the volunteer troops the nickname, the [[Redshirts (Italy)|Camicie rosse]]. The first historical records of the actual Italian military uniform dates back to the Constitution (called [[Statuto Albertino]]) of the [[Royal Italian Army]] ({{lang-it|Regio Esercito Italiano}}) in 1861, the year of [[Italian Unification]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Illustrated-Encyclopaedia-Military-Uniforms-Century/dp/B00FAUOECK/ref=sr_1_77?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1542619437&sr=1-77&keywords=italian+uniforms|title=An Illustrated Encyclopaedia of Military Uniforms of the 19th Century|last=Smith|first=Digby|publisher=LORENZ BOOKS|year=2010|isbn=|location=|pages=|asin=B00FAUOECK}} The soldiers of the Royal Army dressed in green colored uniforms with black boots and helmets.{{Cite book|title=Regio esercito: the italian royal army in mussolini's wars, 1935-1943|last=Cloutier|first=Patrick|publisher=lulu.com|year=2013|isbn=9781105074011|location=|page=232}} The black uniforms of [[Mussolini]]'s militia, the [[Blackshirts|Camicie Nere]], is another symbolic army uniform in Italian history.{{Cite web|url=http://www.regioesercito.it/uniformi/unimilizia.htm|title=Regio Esercito-Uniforms of M.V.S.N.-Regulations|last=|first=|date=|website=Regio Esercito|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-24}} [[Duce|Il Duce]] based these black uniforms on the uniforms of the [[Arditi]], a special unit of the Italian Royal Army that fought in the [[First World War]].{{Cite book|title=Italian Arditi: Elite Assault Troops 1917-20|last=Pirocchi|first=Angelo|last2=Vuksic|first2=Velimir|publisher=Osprey Publishing|year=2004|isbn=9781841766867|location=|page=64}} During the World Wars, uniforms were prepared and manufactured in military factories.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sartoriarecchia.it|title=Military factories|last=|first=|date=2016|website=|publisher=Sartoria Recchia|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite book|title=Uniforms of World War II - Over 250 Uniforms of Armies, Navies and Air Forces of the World|last=Darman|first=Peter|publisher=Amber Books|year=2016|isbn=9781782743293|location=|page=256}} In 2000, the voluntary military service for women was started and female uniforms now represent 7% of all Italian military uniforms.{{Cite web|url=https://www.difesa.it/Legislazione/Norme_in_rete/Pagine/urn_nir_parlamento_legge_1999-10-20_380_2003-06-0901_06_2011_15_08_22.aspx|title=LEGGE 20 ottobre 1999 n.380|last=|first=|date=|website=Ministry of Defence|publisher=Gazzetta Ufficiale|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-05}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.ilgiornale.it/news/politica/mimetica-e-rossetto-lesercito-delle-signore-fa-guerra-ai-1372569.html|title=Mimetica e rossetto. L'Esercito delle signore fa la guerra ai pregiudizi|last=Caminiti|first=Simonetta|date=March 2017|work=Il Giornale|access-date=|language=Italian}} ==Marina Militare (Navy)== [[File:Marina Militare parade (2 june 2007, 401).jpg|300px|left|Uniforms of the Italian Navy in a parade|alt=Italian Navy in a Parade|thumb]] The '''Italian Navy''' ({{lang-it|Marina Militare}}, abbreviated as '''MM''') is the [[Navy]] of the [[Italy|Italian Republic]]. The Italian Navy is divided into different corps: Corps of Staff Officers ('''SM'''), [[Corps of Naval Engineering]] ('''GN'''), Corps of the Naval Arms ('''AN'''), Maritime Military Medical Corps ('''MD''') for medics and for Pharmacists ('''FM'''), Corps of Military Maritime Commissariat ('''CM'''), [[Corps of the Port Captaincies – Coast Guard|Corps of the Port Captaincies]] ('''CP'''), Corps of the Military Maritime Crews ('''CEMM''').{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Army-Navy-Uniforms-Insignia-Countries/dp/B009KDH2UE|title=Army and Navy Uniforms and Insignia: How to Know Rank, Corps and Service in the Military and Naval Forces of the United States and Foreign Countries|last=Williams|first=Dion|publisher=Ulan Press|year=2012|isbn=|location=|page=512|asin=B009KDH2UE}} Since 1861, the materials and uniforms used by the Italian Navy have been adjusted and often re-designed as the service evolved.{{cite web|url=http://www.marina.difesa.it/EN/history/Pagine/default.aspx|title=History and culture|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Navy|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=9 October 2018}}{{Cite book|url=http://www.rodorigoeditore.it/prodotto/le-uniformi-della-marina-militare-vol-dal-1861-al-1918/|title=Le Uniformi della Marina Militare – Vol. I, Dal 1861 al 1918|last=Galuppini|first=Gino|publisher=Rodorigo|year=1997|isbn=|location=|page=248|language=Italian}} The current uniforms are based on the [[Italian Navy ranks|Marina Militare rank system]], and come with variations in rank and on a seasonal basis.{{Cite book|title=Uniforms and Insignia of the Navies of World War Two|last=Mollo|first=Andrew|publisher=Greenhill Books|year=1991|isbn=9781853670978|location=|page=112}} This uniforms also vary depending on the the location where the personnel are serving, with different uniforms for serving on ships, naval planes, [[Submarine|submarines]] or land locations.{{cite web|url=http://www.marina.difesa.it/conosciamoci/uniformi/Pagine/default.aspx|title=Uniforms-Italian Navy|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Navy|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=28 September 2018}} ===Design=== The design of the uniforms are based on the rank of the personnel ([[Official|officials]], [[Marshal (Italy)|marshals]], [[Troop|troops]] and [[Cadet|cadets]]). The uniforms change seasonally for summer and winter, and have different uniforms for the different departments of the Navy. The uniforms are also made of different textile materials. There is also an operational uniform that the Navy uses.{{cite book|url=https://ospreypublishing.com/italian-navy-air-force-elite-units-special-forces-1940-45|title=Italian Navy & Air Force Elite Units & Special Forces 1940–45|last1=Crociani|first1=Piero|last2=Battistelli|first2=Pier Paolo|date=20 January 2013|publisher=Osprey Publishing|year=2013|isbn=978-1849088572|location=|page=64|accessdate=14 November 2018}} ====Regular Uniform==== The standard uniform used by regular troops is the same for male and female personnel, with the exception of the jacket in the winter version (six-buttons for male and a three-buttons for female personnel), and it presents two seasonal variations for summer and winter. The winter uniform is fully colored in a dark-blue, with the same color for its accessories, such as the [[Boonie hat|hat’s brim]] (the hat itself is white on top, with the MM symbol sewn on it), the gloves, shoes and tie. A white shirt is worn underneath. The female personnel are also allowed to carry a bag and substitute the classic cut trousers with a skirt. The summer uniform is composed of a short-sleeved white shirt, worn with another white t-shirt underneath, both of which are tucked into the classical-cut white trousers and tightened by a belt with a golden colored [[buckle]]. The shoes are white, as well as the hat (whose brim remains black like the winter version). As for for the winter version, female personnel can carry a white bag.{{Cite web|url=http://www.marina.difesa.it/conosciamoci/uniformi/Pagine/stagione_graduati.aspx|title=Regular uniform-Navy|last=|first=|date=2015|website=Italian Navy|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ====Ceremonial Uniform==== The ''Ceremonial Uniform'' has two seasonal variations for summer and winter. There are some common features such as the hat, which remains white on top with a black brim and the Italian Navy symbol sewn on the front; the light blue band passing from the right shoulder and tied to the opposite hip; the black shoes and a [[sword]], the [[hilt]] of which is coloured in gold. The different variations are mainly based on the choice of the color and in the weight of the material used. The summer version is lighter and almost entirely white colored, with black and golden shoulder pads. The winter version comes with a six-button black jacket, classical cut black trousers and a white shirt worn underneath. A black tie completes the uniform.{{Cite web|url=http://www.marina.difesa.it/conosciamoci/uniformi/Pagine/stagioni_ufficiali.aspx|title=Ceremonial uniform-Navy|last=|first=|date=2015|website=Italian Navy|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ===Special Forces=== ====GOI==== The Operational Raider Group ({{lang-it|Gruppo Operativo Incursori}}, abbreviated as '''GOI''') is part of the [[Italian special forces|Italian Special Forces]] and is one of the two sections that form the [[Comando Raggruppamento Subacquei e Incursori Teseo Tesei|COMSUBIN]]. The GOI have different uniforms, including a [[scuba diving]] one. After being transported in a submarine, they use diving in order to stealthily reach places while remaining undercover. Another characteristic of this uniform is the [[Safety harness|harness]] used for steep access and egress points above water.{{cite web |title=GOI |url=http://www.marina.difesa.it/formazione-in-marina/formazione_specialistica/ilgoi/Pagine/default.aspx |website=Italian Navy |publisher=Ministero della Difesa |accessdate=25 November 2018}} ====GOS==== The Operational Divers Group ({{lang-it|Gruppo Operativo Subacquei}}, abbreviated as '''GOS''') is a special unit that is deployed for conducting any interventions in depths (of the sea) that reach more than 1000 meters underwater. The uniform used is fully black, with transparent scuba glasses, a torch mounted on top of the helmet and two [[Oxygen tank|oxygen tanks]] attached to the back of the operator.{{Cite web|url=http://www.marina.difesa.it/formazione-in-marina/formazione_specialistica/ilgos/Pagine/galelria_gos.aspx|title=Italian Navy-Gallery|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Navy|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}} ==Esercito Italiano (Army)== [[File:Uniformi esercito collage.jpg|thumb|380x340px|left|Uniforms of the Italian Army |alt=]] The uniforms that are currently in use by the '''Italian Army''' ({{lang-it|Esercito Italiano}}, abbreviated as '''EI''') can be divided into four "families": the ''Regular Uniform'' (the only one that includes seasonal variations), the ''Service Uniform'', the ''Service Combat Uniform'', and the ''Ceremonial Uniform'' (only for Officials).{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/Equipment/Militaria/Uniforms|title=Uniforms|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-02}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.it/Enciclopedia-Rizzoli-Larousse-Volumi-Biblioteca-Sapere/dp/B010RBUDA8|title=Enciclopedia Larousse, la biblioteca del sapere|last=Larousse|first=Pierre|publisher=Corriere della Sera-Rizzoli Larousse S.p.a.|year=2004|isbn=|volume=22|location=Rotolito Lombarda, Pioltello (Milano)|pages=12|language=Italian|asin=B010RBUDA8}} There are precise laws that regulate Armed Forces’ uniforms regarding the type of material, color and [[badge]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/uniforme|title=uniforme nell'Enciclopedia Treccani|last=Treccani|first=Giovanni|last2=Gentile|first2=Giovanni|date=|publisher=Treccani|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.gazzettaufficiale.it/eli/id/2012/09/25/012G0183/sg/|title=Article 300, clause 4, n. 66|last=Ministry of Defence|date=2010|website=Gazzetta Ufficiale|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-13}} These military uniforms can only be sold to verified collectors and Army personnel.{{Cite web|url=https://www.brocardi.it/testo-unico-pubblica-sicurezza/titolo-ii/capo-iii/art28.html|title=Licenza ex art.28 T.U.L.P.S.|date=|website=Brocardi|publisher=Gazzetta Ufficiale|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-05}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.cambridge.org/it/academic/subjects/history/twentieth-century-regional-history/italian-army-and-first-world-war?format=PB&isbn=9780521149372|title=The Italian Army and the First World War|last=Gooch|first=John|publisher=University of Leeds|year=2014|isbn=9780521149372|location=|pages=}} Civilians are allowed buy the ordinary uniform without the Army’s [[coat of arms]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.difesa.it/SMD_/Staff/Reparti/V/RegolamentoUniformi/Pagine/default.aspx|title=Regulation for uniforms-Defence|last=|first=|date=|website=Ministry of Defence|publisher=Gazzetta Ufficiale|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/equipment/militaria|title=Militaria|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-13}} ===Design=== ====Regular Uniform==== The ''Regular Uniform'' consists of a [[single-breasted]] jacket with four buttons and four pockets. Trousers come with a classic cut and the front [[Pleat|pleats]] have five pockets, one of which is for a pocket watch. The shirt worn underneath also has two small pockets. The uniform is completed with a necktie, brown leather gloves, brown shoes, khaki socks and a [[cap]] or [[Headgear|headdress]]. Both summer and winter versions differ from each other in the materials that are used when making them.{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/Equipment/Militaria/Uniforms/Pagine/Uniforme-Ordinaria-e-derivate.aspx|title=Regular uniform|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-08}}{{cite book|url=http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a507638.pdf|title=ITALIAN ARMY: THE ORDINARY SOLDIER. FROM THE ANALYSIS OF THE PAST, THE INSTRUMENT OF THE FUTURE|last1=Sganga|first1=Rodolfo|publisher=Marine Corps University|year=2006|isbn=|location=|pages=|accessdate=20 November 2018}} ==== Service Uniform ==== [[File:Italian Soldier Olypmic Games Turin 2006.jpg|216x216px|Service Combat Uniform of the Italian Army|alt=woman soldier's uniform of the Italian Army|thumb]] The summer and winter ''Service Uniform'' have identical cuts and colors with the Regular uniform, while active military personnel always utilize a special headdress.{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/Equipment/Militaria/Uniforms/Pagine/Uniforme-di-Servizio-e-derivate.aspx|title=Service uniform|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-08}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.quora.com/How-good-is-the-Italian-army-now|title=How good is the Italian Army now?|last=Rebellato|first=Alberto|date=30 April 2017|work=Quora|access-date=}} ====Service Combat Uniform==== The ''Service Combat Uniform'' is the most used uniform, and it is distributed to all soldiers with the same mimetic [[pattern]] ([[Paratrooper|paratroopers]] have a different model with a strengthening on the shoulders). It is composed of a [[beret]], a five button closure jacket with two internal pockets, and trousers with four pockets: two posterior and one in the middle of each thigh.{{Cite book|title=Italian Army Elite Units & Special Forces 1940–43|last=Battistelli|first=Pier Paolo|last2=Shumate|first2=Jhonny|publisher=Osprey Publishing|year=2011|isbn=9781849085953|location=|page=64}} Accessories completing the uniform include gloves, special footwear and a t-shirt with short or long sleeves, depending on the season. If the activity or the situation requires so, a raincoat made up of a thermo lining and a warm windbreaker are added. The Combat version is composed of a [[helmet]], an anti-reflection [[Tarpaulin|tarp]], a scarf and a belt with glove compartment to the basic Service Uniform. When needed, the uniform is equipped with a [[bulletproof vest]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/Equipment/Militaria/Uniforms/Pagine/Uniforme-di-Servizio-e-Combattimento-e-derivate.aspx|title=Service Combat uniform|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-02}} Alpines troops utilize a different hat, with an eagle feather on the left side, and each unit has a different pompom color.{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldwar1.com/itafront/equip_w.htm|title=La Grande Guerra: Weapons, Equipment, Uniforms - Unique to the Italian Front, Part I. Italian Forces|last=Benedetti|first=Leo|last2=Hanlon|first2=Michael|date=2000|website=World War I|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-08}} ====Ceremonial Uniform==== The ''Ceremonial Uniform'' includes a [[Double-breasted|double-breasted jacket]] with six buttons and two pockets on the hips. Trousers come with a classic cut in fabric, as well as the jacket. The winter version is composed of a blue [[cape]] infantry, a black rigid cap, white gloves and black shoes. There are other accessories such as the necktie, a light blue scarf and a [[sabre]] that complete the uniform.{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/Equipment/Militaria/Uniforms/Pagine/Uniforme-da-Cerimonia.aspx|title=Ceremonial uniform|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-08}} [[File:U cer.jpg|thumb|320x320px|Cerimonial uniforms of the Italian Army|alt=]] ===Historical Uniforms=== Historical uniforms are used in [[Military high school|Military schools]], the [[Military academy|Military Academy]], [[Non-commissioned officer|NCO]] schools and some [[Regiment|regiments]]. They recall the light blue uniforms of the Savoy army. The Armed Force’s choice of headgear is the [[beret]], used since the 1980s (adapted from the [[side cap]]), and is the most worn headdress by Italian troops.{{Cite news|url=http://www.lonesentry.com/articles/intelligence-report/italian-soldier.html|title=The individual soldier (Italy)|last=US War department|first=|date=December 1942|work=Intelligence bulletin|access-date=}} Each color or model has an historical reason and it also exists in a female version. The [[ribbon]] on the cylindrical part of the headgear differs for the Officials.{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/Equipment/Militaria/Uniforms/Pagine/Copricapo.aspx|title=Headgear|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-11}} ====Grey-green==== Italian military troops adopted the ''grey-green uniform'' during the World War I.{{cite book|title=Italian Army during World War I|last1=Nicolle|first1=David|publisher=BAM – Biblioteca d’arte militare|year=2014|isbn=9788861021815|edition=Soldati, n. 77|location=|page=90|language=Italian}} It was Luigi Brioschi, president of the Milanese section of the C.A.I. ([[Italian Alpine Club]]) in 1905 who presented a combat uniform more suitable for modern war, replacing the showy uniforms of the [[Royal Sardinian Army]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/storia/grande-guerra/Pagine/Equipaggiamenti-e-Uniformi.aspx|title=Equipment and Uniforms|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-22}}{{cite book|url=https://issuu.com/rivista.militare1/docs/l-uniforme_gigio_verde-1909-1918|title=Grey-green uniform1909-1918|last1=Viotti|first1=Andrea|date=1994|publisher=Studi di Uniformologia SME Ufficio Storico|isbn=|location=Rome|pages=|language=Italian|accessdate=14 November 2018}} Brioschi demonstrated that the grey uniforms used by the Arditi were less visible to enemy [[Sniper|snipers]], and so the project was financed.{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/history/pagine/the-grey-green-uniform.aspx|title=Grey-green uniform|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-11}} Grey-green uniforms have been utilized for forty years, including in the two World Wars.{{cite news |last1=Budanovic |first1=Nikola |title=Elite Italian Shock Troops - The Arditi: We either win, or we all die! |url=https://www.google.it/search?q=regular+uniform+italian+army&ei=xMTzW8WCO5HyauP_jtgB&start=40&sa=N&ved=0ahUKEwjF9NnpxeLeAhURuRoKHeO_Axs4HhDy0wMIjAE&biw=1366&bih=705 |accessdate=20 November 2018 |publisher=War history online |date=2 December 2016}} Nowadays they are a symbol for the Army and some Army Corps still currently use them for special occasions.{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/History/Pagine/Historical-Uniforms-in-the-twentieth-century.aspx|title=Historical uniforms in the twentieth century|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-13}}{{cite web |title=Italian Army |url=https://ww2-weapons.com/italian-army/ |date=2017|website=Italian Army in WW1 |publisher=World War 2 Weapons |accessdate=20 November 2018}} ====Model 40==== It was possible to update the grey-green uniforms in order to adjust them for [[World War II]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.carabinieri.it/arma/ieri/equipaggiamento-e-materiali/1910-1940/le-uniformi/la-riforma-baistrocchi|title=Riforma Baistrocchi|last=Baistrocchi|first=Federico|date=1933|website=Carabinieri|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-11}} The Officials, NCOs and troops uniforms differed from each other in the cloth’s quality  and workmanship. The Model 40 uniform abolished the colored or black velvet [[Collar (clothing)|collars]]. Troops had a three-button jacket (known also as a sahariana), which included four patch-pockets with a central pleat closed by small buttons, and it was partially lined. Trousers were different for [[cavalry]] and [[infantry]].{{Cite book|title=The Italian Army 1940-45 (3): Italy 1943-45: Italy 1943-45 v. 3 (Men-at-Arms)|last=Jowett|first=Philip|publisher=Osprey Publishing|year=2001|isbn=9781855328662|location=|page=48}} They were secured on the calf by knee-length socks or by leather [[chaps]]. A cloth belt with small buttons clamped around the waist. NCOs and Officials utilized a lighter color than troops, and they were allowed to adapt their uniforms during the war.{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/history/pagine/uniforms-in-the-2nd-world-war.aspx|title=Model 40 uniform in the World War II|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-11}} ====Khaki==== During the Italian War of Liberation in 1943, the personnel received [[Khaki drill|khaki]] uniforms from the [[British Army|British Army,]] including a short jacket with a button panel in sight and two large pockets with a button and turn-up.{{cite news |last1=Tynan |first1=Jane |title=Why First World War soldiers wore khaki |url=http://ww1centenary.oucs.ox.ac.uk/material/why-first-world-war-soldiers-wore-khaki/ |accessdate=20 November 2018 |publisher=WW1 centenary |date=2013}} Trousers had six pockets and they were secured to the ankles through two [[canvas]] buckles.{{Cite book|url=https://www.abebooks.it/servlet/BookDetailsPL?bi=22774989235&cm_mmc=gmc-_-nonisbn-_-PLA-_-v01&product=bi:%2022774989235&gclid=Cj0KCQiA28nfBRCDARIsANc5BFBK4uzyGqVAkxhfR_g8PpEK-fkENw0R_BlbLDIheIJbyHGQgbQizlwaAueDEALw_wcB|title=Italian Military Uniforms from 1861 until now|last=Del Giudice|first=Elio|last2=Del Giudice|first2=Vittorio|publisher=Bramante|year=2000|isbn=|location=Milan|pages=|language=Italian|access-date=2018-11-19}} The footwear used were long black boots that came up to the ankle. A [[Campaign hat|campaign hat]] and pan helmet completed the uniform. The recognizable elements of the Italian khaki uniforms were the insignia and the [[Italian Army ranks|grade emblems]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/history/pagine/uniforms-in-the-war-of-liberation-1943–the-combat-groups.aspx|title=Khaki uniforms in the War of Liberation in 1943|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-11}} Despite paratroopers preferring the khaki uniforms, they continued to wear the grey-green berets, helmets and the traditional campaign hats. ===Special Forces=== ====Folgore==== On 10 June 1967, the Paratroopers Brigade granted the name “[[Paratroopers Brigade Folgore|Folgore]]” to the Battaglione Paracadutisti, and the beret’s color subsequently changed to [[Amaranth (color)|amaranth]] (a colour adopted by many military departments all over the world).{{Cite web|url=http://www.folgore.it|title=Folgore-paratroopers and militaria|last=|first=|date=|website=Folgore|publisher=Italian Army (special forces)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-05}}[[File:1st Sardinia Grenadiers Bastille Day 2007 n1.jpg|thumbnail|227x227px|Uniform of the first Sardinia Grenadiers|alt=|left]] ====Col Moschin==== The [[9th Paratroopers Assault Regiment|Italian 9th paratrooper assault regiment]] is a special forces’ department of the Italian Army. In 1997, Col Moschin re-adopted the traditional insignia of the Arditi in the Great War. It was added to the bomb with a flame on the left, overlapped by two crossed [[Dagger|daggers]], the paratrooper’s [[Parachute|canopy]] and the right wing of the Aviotruppe’s medal.{{Cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/en/equipment/militaria/patches/pagine/infantry-and-specialties-paratroopers.aspx|title=Infantry and specialities-Paratroopers|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Army|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-02}} ====Granatieri di Sardegna==== The [[Granatieri di Sardegna Mechanized Brigade|Granatieri di Sardegna]] is one of the oldest regiments in the Italian army. The force originated in [[Sardinia]] is now based in Rome. This corp is responsible for the guarding of the [[President of Italy|president]]. The regiment has its own traditional uniform. The uniform is black with red ornaments and contains a big black hat almost similar to that of the [[Queen's Guard|British Queen's Guard]]. ====Alpini==== The [[Alpini]] are the oldest mountain infantry in the world and one of the Italian special forces.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1917/12/14/archives/fought-till-death-to-delay-austrians-bersaglieri-and-alpini-in-the.html|title=FOUGHT TILL DEATH TO DELAY AUSTRIANS; Bersaglieri and Alpini in the Mountains|last=Gibbon|first=Perceval|date=14 December 1917|work=New York Times|access-date=}} A special feature of their uniform is the ''[[Cappello Alpino]]'', that carries a black [[raven]] feather, a garment that gave this force the nickname: "The Black feathers" ({{lang-it|"Le Penne Nere"}}). Officers traditionally had a white [[eagle]] feather instead of the black one.{{Cite web|url=http://www.smalp155.org/curiosita/enciclopedia/cappello-alpino.php|title=Cappello Alpino|last=|first=|date=|website=Small 155|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}} When the force was created, the hat worn was made of black [[felt]]. This was changed when the new green-grey uniform was adopted in 1909. Since then, the hat was changed to the distinctive grey felt that is currently being used.{{Cite web|url=http://www.vecio.it/cms/index.php/armiequipaggiamento/divise-ed-equipaggiamento|title=Vecio.it - Alpini's history - Uniforms and equipment|last=|first=|date=|website=Vecio|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}} The Alpini has distinctive green [[Cuff|cuffs]] on the dark blue tunics worn for full dress and barrack dress before 1915, and by the green piping on their light blue/grey trousers. When grey-green service uniforms were tried out by the Alpini in 1906, before the entire army adopted them in 1909, the distinctive green collar patches and typical headdress were retained and are still in service. ==Aeronautica Militare (Air Force)== [[File:Italian Air Force uniform.jpg|thumb|365x365px|Historical Italian Air Force Uniform of WWII|alt=]] ===Design=== The uniforms of the '''Italian Air Force''' ({{lang-it|Aeronautica Militare}}, abbreviated as '''AM''') includes a hand-tailored dress [[tunic]] that is made of a medium blue-grey colored [[wool]]. The uniform consists of a buttoned jacket and trousers, with a double buckled belt holding the jacket together to make the appearance of the serviceman more neat and trimmed down. It is worn with a white shirt and a blue or black tie.{{Cite book|title=The Royal Italian Air Force, 1923-1945|last=Coil|first=Spencer|publisher=Schiffer Pub Ltd|year=2009|isbn=9780764333736|location=|page=256}} The first planes of the Italian Air Force were not equipped with a closed cabin for the [[Aircraft pilot|pilots]], so earlier versions of the uniforms for pilots included helmets and goggles. ====Regular Uniform==== The Air Force uniform no longer includes the helmets as part of the standard uniform.{{cite web|url=http://www.rathbonemuseum.com/IT/ITCol/ItalianColonel.html|title=Regio Air Force|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Rathbone Museum|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 November 2018}} The uniforms vary also according to their department. These can be classified in the ''training department'', ''flight department'', ''support department'', ''aerial defence department'' and a unit consisting of production.{{cite web|url=http://www.aeronautica.difesa.it/organizzazione/REPARTI/Pagine/default.aspx|title=Air force Departments|last=|first=|date=|website=Italian Air Force|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=12 November 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/Visit/Museum-Exhibits/Fact-Sheets/Display/Article/196879/wwii-royal-italian-air-force/|title=WWII Royal Italian Air Force|last=|first=|date=4 May 2015|work=National Museum of the US Air Force|access-date=2018-11-19}} Unique to the Air Force uniforms is that in the public sector, the brand Aeronautica Militare has the license given by the Italian Air Force to produce and sell fashion that is based on the looks and designs of the Air Force uniforms.{{cite web|url=https://www.aeronauticamilitare-collezioneprivata.it/en/company|title=Company I Air Force|last=|first=|date=2017-07-21|website=Italian Air Force|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 November 2018}} ===Special Forces=== ====17° Stormo Incursori==== This Italian Air Force special forces unit, the [[17º Stormo Incursori|17th Raiders Wing]] ({{lang-it|17° Stormo Incursori}}), was created during the Second World War. They are equipped with a military green uniform, including a multi-pocket jacket used to hold any kind of equipment or other devices needed in order to ensure versatility and total functionality when in use.{{cite web|url=http://en.difesaonline.it/evidenza/approfondimenti/17°-stormo-incursori-e-la-lotta-mani-nude|title=17° Flocking and fighting with bare hands|last=|first=|date=|website=Difesa Online|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=12 November 2018}} ==Arma dei Carabinieri (Gendarmerie)== [[File:Carb1875.jpg|thumb|300x310px|left|Uniform of a Carabiniere in the 19th Century |alt=]] [[File:Carabiniere a Bologna (April 2006).jpg|195px|Traditional black with red stripe Carabinieri's uniform|alt=Uniform of a Carabieri's soldier|thumb]] In Italy, there are two police forces. The regular state police, the [[Polizia_di_Stato|Polizia]], and the '''Carabinieri'''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-28254297|title=It's 200 years old, but what is Italy's carabinieri?|last=Mitzman|first=Dany|date=13 July 2014|work=BBC News|access-date=}} The [[Carabinieri]] were part of the Italian Army until the early 2000s. Since then, they are considered as an independent part of the Italian Armed Forces.{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Carabiniere|title=Carabiniere - Italian Police|last=Macfarquhar|first=Colin|last2=Bell|first2=Andrew|date=|editor-last=Smellie|editor-first=William|website=Britannica|publisher=Encyclopaedia Britannica|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=1 November 2018}} The first nine written rules about [[Tuscany]] uniforms for Carabinieri date back to 9 August 1814 and recite the first design of the uniforms.{{cite web|url=http://www.carabinieri.it/arma/curiosita/non-tutti-sanno-che/u/uniforme-dei-carabinieri|title=Uniforms of Carabinieri|last=|first=|date=|website=Carabinieri|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=1 October 2018}} ===Design=== The uniform that the [[Gendarmerie]] wore in 1814 consisted of a [[Turquoise (color)|turquoise]] fabric buttoned suit with a blue collar and padded gloves. Since 1822, some small changes have been made to the uniform. Officials and Marshals had silver swords and sabers, both in a black leather [[scabbard]]. At the beginning of the 20th Century, the rules of the dress code were reinforced because of World War I. Troops had three different types of uniforms: the ''Complete uniform'', the ''Ordinary uniform'', and the ''Effort uniform''. In 1940, Italy was one of the many countries that fought in World War II. The Carabinieri's uniform at that time was made of a green-grey cloth material, and was used by all soldiers.{{cite web|url=http://www.carabinieri.it/arma/ieri/equipaggiamento-e-materiali/1910-1940/le-uniformi/l%27uniforme-di-guerra---1940|title=War uniform - 1940|last=|first=|date=|website=Carabinieri|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=8 October 2018}} ====Ceremonial Uniform==== For historical and ceremonial use, the Carabinieri uniform consists of a distinctive black uniform made of silver [[Braid|braids]] around the collar and cuffs, edges trimmed in scarlet and [[epaulettes]] in silver. The fringes of the mounted division are white, and the infantry has light blue. The headgear used is the traditional two-pointed hat for Carabinieri, known as the Lucerna, also called a [[bicorne]].{{cite web|url=http://www.relicmilitaria.com/product/italy-italian-carabinieri-lucernabicorne-hatceremonial-headdress-circa-1970s-scarce/|title=Bicorne hat, ceremonial headdress|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Relic Militaria|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=10 November 2018}} In the Eighties [[Giorgio Armani]] designed the new more modern uniforms.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2014/jul/10/giorgio-armani-80-eight-facts-fashion-designer|title=Giorgio Armani at 80: eight things you didn't know about the fashion designer|last=Cochrane|first=Lauren|date=10 July 2014|work=The Guardian|access-date=}} ====Regular Uniform==== The modern Carabinieri Force uniform is colored in black for every seasonal version, with small variations on weather basis (coat or wind jacket), and is composed of a four-button jacket with [[Shoulder pads (fashion)|shoulder pads]]: all buttons on the uniform are silvered. The shirt underneath is white, with two pockets. The trousers have a classic cut, with four pockets and has two vertical red stripes along the outer side of both legs, stretching from the hips to the ankles. Flat black shoes are worn. The uniform is accompanied by accessories such as the black tie and, occasionally, black leather gloves. The rigid hat presents the Arma’s frieze.{{cite web|url=http://www.carabinieri.it/arma/oggi/uniformi/classificazione|title=Regular uniform-Carabinieri|last=|first=|date=|website=Carabinieri|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=8 October 2018}}[[File:Firenze.Carabinieri01.JPG|thumb|195px|Uniforms of Carabinieri at a manifestation|alt=]] ===Special Forces=== Under the Carabinieri, there are also special police forces in charge with both internal and external security, each with their own uniforms. ====GIS==== The Carabinieri's section of [[Gruppo di intervento speciale|Special Intervention Group]] ({{lang-it|Gruppo di Intervento Speciale}}, abbreviated as '''GIS''') is an [[Counter-terrorism|anti-terrorism]] unit founded in 1978. The color of the uniform utilized by this élite force is usually the dark blue, even though mimetic and desert variations exist.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101208033140/http://www.specialoperations.com/Foreign/Italy/GIS.htm|title=GIS|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Special Operations|publisher=Carabinieri|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Reinforcements such as helmets, [[Knee pad|knee pads]], [[Elbow pad|elbow pads]] or bulletproof jackets are composed of fireproof and insulating materials.{{cite web|url=http://www.carabinieri.it/multilingua/en/english/the-nuclei-investigativi-carabinieri-r-o-s-and-g-i-s-|title=THE NUCLEI INVESTIGATIVI, CARABINIERI R.O.S. AND G.I.S.|last=|first=|date=|website=Carabinieri|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 November 2018}} ====Calabrian and Sardinian Hunters==== [[Carabinieri Helicopter Squadron "Cacciatori di Calabria"|Calabrian and Sardinian Hunters]] ({{lang-it|Cacciatori di Calabria, Cacciatori di Sardegna}}) are one of the special section of support for the Arma dei Carabinieri. Due to the generally milder weather and the rocky features of the southern landscape, the Hunters' uniforms consist of a lighter battle dress with a dark green [[camouflage]] pattern, together with leather gloves and combat boots. Also present with the uniform is a distinctive bright red beret, with the Carabinieri symbol sewn onto it.{{cite web|url=http://en.difesaonline.it/evidenza/approfondimenti/squadrone-eliportato-carabinieri-cacciatori-di-calabria-al-poligono-di-tiro|title=CARABINIERI SQUADRON. CALABRIAN HUNTERS: AT THE SHOOTING RANGE|last=|first=|date=|website=Difesa online|publisher=Ministry of Defence|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 November 2018}} ====Sicilian Hunters==== The [[Carabinieri Helicopter Squadron "Cacciatori di Sicilia"|Sicilian Hunters]] ({{lang-it|Cacciatori di Sicilia}}) are a special paratroop unit of the Carabinieri based in [[Sicilly|Sicily]]. This unit is mainly tasked to search for fugitives in the Sicilian mountains. Besides the normal Carabinieri uniforms, this troop also possesses operational uniforms like the other Hunter squadrons. The operative uniform has an extra blue [[neckerchief]], leather gloves and combat boots.{{cite web|url=http://www.carabinieri.it/arma/oggi/uniformi/classificazione/accessori-uniforme-operativa|title=Operative uniform's accessories|last=|first=|date=|website=Carabinieri|publisher=Ministry of Defence|language=Italian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 November 2018}} ==See also== * [[Italian Armed Forces]] * [[Italian special forces]] * [[Equipment of the Italian Army]] *[[Italian special forces|Italian Special Forces]] *[[Military uniform]] ==References== {{reflist|group=4}} ==External links== *[https://www.difesa.it/EN/ Official Site of Italian Ministry of Defense] *[http://www.esercito.difesa.it/EN/ Official Site of Italian Army] *[http://www.marina.difesa.it/EN/ Official Site of Italian Navy] *[http://www.carabinieri.it/multilingua/en/ Official Site of Carabinieri] *{{It icon}} [http://www.aeronautica.difesa.it/ Official Site of Italian Air Force] [[Category:Italian Army]] [[Category:Italian Navy]] [[Category:Uniforms]] [[Category:Military of Italy]] [[Category:Marina Militare]] [[Category:Gendarmerie]] [[Category:Border guards]] [[Category:Italian Air Force]] [[Category:Italian Army]] [[Category:Italian Navy]] [[Category:Carabinieri]] [[Category:Uniforms]] [[Category:Military of Italy]] [[Category:Military uniforms]] [[Category:Marina Militare]] [[Category:Aeronautica Militare]] [[Category:Gendarmerie]] [[Category:Border guards]] [[Category:Military provosts]] [[Category:1814 establishments in Italy]] [[Category:1814 establishments in Italy]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox desalination plant | name = Witsand Solar Desalination Plant | image = | caption = | location_map = South Africa | location = [[Witsand]], [[Hessequa Local Municipality|Hessequa Municipality]], [[Western Cape|Western Cape Province]] | coordinates = {{coord|34|23|48|S|20|50|51|E|display=inline,title}} | estimated output = {{convert|100,000|liters|m3}} of water daily | extended output = | cost =ZAR:8.6 million (US$650,000)<ref name="1R"/> | energy usage = | energy generation offset = | cost offsets = | technology = [[Sedimentation]], [[Reverse osmosis]], [[Water chlorination|Chlorination]] | percent of water supply = | operation date = October 2018 (Expected) | website = }} '''Witsand Solar Desalination Plant''' ('''WSDP'''), is a water purification project, under construction in [[South Africa]].<ref name="2R">{{cite web|access-date=23 July 2018 |date=18 July 2018 |url=https://www.news24.com/Green/News/revolutionary-solar-power-desalination-plant-could-provide-cheaper-option-but-it-needs-space-20180718 |title=Revolutionary Solar-Power Desalination Plant Could Provide Cheaper Option, but It Needs Space | author=Melanie Gosling | publisher=News24Wire.com |location=Cape Town}}</ref><ref name="3R">{{cite web|access-date=23 July 2018 | url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/national/2018-07-16-france-to-help-drought-hit-witsand-with-solar-power-desalination-plant/ |date=16 July 2018 |publisher=[[Business Day (South Africa)]] | title=France to help drought-hit Witsand with solar-power desalination plant |first=Linda |last=Ensor}}</ref>
==Location== The water treatment facility is under construction in the seaside town of [[Witsand]], in [[Hessequa Local Municipality]], in the [[Western Cape|Western Cape Province]], at the mouth of the [[Breede River]].<ref name="2R"/> This is approximately {{convert|305|km|0}}, by road, south-east of [[Cape Town]], the nearest large city.<ref name="4R">{{cite web|date=23 July 2018 | url=https://distancecalculator.globefeed.com/South_Africa_Distance_Result.asp?fromplace=Cape%20Town%20City%20Centre%2C%20Cape%20Town%2C%20South%20Africa&toplace=Witsand%2C%20South%20Africa&dt1=ChIJ6U_uo2NnzB0R9eheP_JsUZU&dt2=ChIJ6fOqquJG0R0REXGBzh5BKc0&sr=dc |title=Distance between Cape Town City Centre, Cape Town, South Africa and Witsand, South Africa |access-date=23 July 2018 | author=Globefeed.com |publisher=Globefeed.com}}</ref>
==Overview== The town of Witsand is a tourist attraction, with a low-season population of approximately 300 people. During the tourist high-season, the population swells to over 3,000 people, leading to freshwater scarcity in the town.To address that scarcity, the government of the Western Cape and the French government, decided to jointly develop and fund he Witsand water purification project.<ref name="2R"/>
==Technology== The WSDP is the first desalination plant in South Africa, that uses solar energy to power its processes. Its new technology applications, allow for the elimination of storage batteries in the design.<ref name="3R"/> The plant's new '''Osmosun technology''', involves the use of a specialized "intelligent" membrane that is able to continue delivering [[reverse osmosis]], even when the sun goes behind a cloud, thus reducing the amount of solar energy delivered. The energy delivered would increase again when the clouds moved away. That ability to "soften" the variability in the energy delivered, preserves the reverse osmosis membrane. At night, when there is no sun, the design allows the plant to switch to conventional grid-electricity and continue working all through the darkness, until the sun rises the next morning.<ref name="2R"/>
==Construction and cost== The budgeted cost of the plant is ZAR:8.6 million (approx. US$650,000), to be shared equally between the governments of the Western Cape and that of France.<ref name="1R">{{cite web| url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/western-cape/france-co-funds-r86m-desalination-plant-in-western-cape-16055049 | title=France co-funds R8.6 million desalination plant in Western Cape |publisher=[[Independent Online (South Africa)]] (IOL) | date=16 July 2018 |access-date=23 July 2018 |last=Ferreira | first=Emsie |location=South Africa}}</ref> The unit cost of the purified water at this plant is between ZAR:7 to ZAR:8 (US$0.52 to US$0.60) for every {{convert|1000|liters|0}}. In comparison, the temporary diesel-fueled desalination plant at [[Strandfontein, Cape Town|Strandfontein]], in Cape Town, produces potable water at ZAR:35 to ZAR:40 (US$2.62 to US$3.00) for every 1,000 liters. If this project is a success, it might be reproduced in other parts of the country, where drought is a problem.<ref name="2R"/>
==Challenges== In order to generate enough solar energy for its internal processes, the plant needs {{convert|3.5|ha|acre}} to accommodate the requisite solar panels. This requirement for large areas to install solar panels, may restrict the project's reproducibility in crowded cities like Cape Town.<ref name="2R"/>

The '''Zeitgeschichtliche Forschungsstelle Ingolstadt e. V.''' (''Ingolstadt Research Institute for Contemporary Historical Research [[Eingetragener Verein|registered association]]'', ''ZFI'', also known as ''Institut für Zeitgeschichtsforschung Ingolstadt'') is a [[Historical revisionism|historical revisionist]] association located in [[Dunsdorf]], [[Bavaria]].<ref>Anton Maegerle, Daniel Hörsch: ''„Der Kampf um die Köpfe“ hat begonnen. Vordenker, Strategen und Wegbereiter rechter Netzwerke''. In: Stephan Braun, Daniel Hörsch (Hrsg.): ''Rechte Netzwerke, eine Gefahr''. VS Verlag für Sozialwissenschaften, Wiesbaden 2004, {{ISBN|3-8100-4153-X}}, p. 114.</ref>
==Political orientation==
The ZFI was founded in 1981 and shaped by [[Alfred Schickel]], [[Hellmut Diwald]] and {{illm|Alfred Seidl|de|Alfred Seidl}}, in opposition to the renowned [[Institut für Zeitgeschichte]] (Institut für Contemporary History) in [[Munich]].<ref name="redok 06-12-14">[http://www.redok.de/content/view/493/36/ ''Geschichtsrevisionistischer Verein'']. redok, 14 December 2006</ref> It has about 500 to 600 members. It organizes large meetings twice a year, and publishes the ''Zeitgeschichtliche Bibliothek'' and the ''ZFI-Informationen''.<ref>Andreas Angerstorfer, Annemarie Dengg: ''Rechte Strukturen in Bayern. Eine Dokumentation mit Schwerpunkt Oberbayern, Oberpfalz und Niederbayern.'' Second revised edition, Munich 2005, p.131</ref> Stephen E. Atkins has stated that the ZFI is a Holocaust denial institution in Germany, while the head of the ZFI, Alfred Schickel, is careful to avoid German restrictions against disputing the Holocaust and has concentrated on what Atkins describes as “so-called [[Allied war crimes during World War II|Allied atrocities]] against the Germans”.<ref>{{Cite book|first=Stephen E.|last=Atkins|authorlink=Stephen E. Atkins|title=Holocaust denial as an international movement|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2009|page=105|ISBN=978-0-313-34538-8}}</ref> For instance, Schickel wrote in 1980 that the number of six millions Jews killed in the [[Holocaust]] was “no longer advocated seriously today in contemporary historical science”.<ref>“heute in der zeitgeschichtlichen Wissenschaft nicht mehr ernsthaft vertreten”, Alfred Schickel in ''Deutschland in Geschichte und Gegenwart'', 1980, cited from: Geschichtsrevisionistischer Verein, ''redok'', 14 December 2006</ref> "The ZFI rejects the findings of historical research, and uses ideologically based [[pseudohistory]]. In doing so, it creates a "parallel universe" isolated from scholarly discourse by self-referencing to its own publications."<ref>{{Cite book|last1=Benz |first1=Wolfgang |authorlink1=Wolfgang Benz |last2=Reif-Spirek |first2=Peter |authorlink2=Peter Reif-Spirek|title=Geschichtsmythen|publisher=Metropol|year=2003|ISBN=978-3-936411-28-7|pages=60–62}}</ref> In conferences and meetings, [[Nazism|National Socialism]] is trivialized, and the German guilt for the [[Second World War]] is denied. This happens in close collaboration with periodicals such as ''[[Europa Vorn]]'', ''[[Nation und Europa]]'' and ''{{illm|Deutschland in Geschichte und Gegenwart|de|Grabert_Verlag#Geschichte}}'', which pursue similar goals.<ref name="Wagner">{{Cite book|first=Bernd|author=Wagner|title=Handbuch Rechtsextremismus. Netzwerke, Parteien, Organisationen, Ideologiezentren, Medien|location=Reinbek bei Hamburg|year=1994|page=164}}</ref> The founders of ZFI, who except for Schickel have died, have collaborated with historical revisionist and [[Radical right (Europe)|Radical right]] organizations.<ref name="redok 06-12-14"/> Former [[GDR]] policeman {{illm|Bernd Wagner|de|Bernd Wagner (Kriminalist)}} regarded the ZFI in 1994 as "one of the intellectual centers of [[Far right in Germany|far right]] [[historical revisionism]] in Germany".<ref name="Wagner" />
==Criticism==
The ZFI was previously observed by the intelligence service of the Bavarian government. However, the ZFI no longer features in the yearly reports of the intelligence service, that depict extremist and anti-constitutional activities. In February 2007, the service stated, though, that "Publications belonging to the far right refer to the Head of the ZFI and his articles in order to propagate thoughts which are not compatible with the free democratic order." <ref>„Dagegen propagieren einschlägige rechtsextremistische Publikationen unter Berufung auf die Person des Leiters der ZFI und seine Artikel vereinzelt auch ein mit der freiheitlichen demokratischen Grundordnung nicht vereinbares Gedankengut.“, ''Bayerischer Landtag'', [http://www.bayern.landtag.de/ElanTextAblage_WP15/Drucksachen/Schriftliche%20Anfragen/15_0007335.pdf Drucksache 15/7335], 22 February 2007, Answer to a written inquiry by the deputy Florian Ritter, [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]] (pdf)</ref>
The [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]] and others have made allegations that {{illm|Alfred Lehmann|de|Alfred_Lehmann_(Politiker,_1950)}} ([[Christian Social Union of Bavaria|CSU]]), Lord Mayor of Ingolstadt, has participated several times in ZFI conferences, while [[Horst Seehofer]] (CSU), the minister for food, agriculture and consumer protection, had sent a laudatory greeting to the organization.<ref name="redok 06-12-14"/><ref>SPD-Pressestelle: [http://www.spd-landtag.de/aktuell/presse_anzeigen.cfm?mehr=7135 ''SPD-Rechtspolitiker Florian Ritter sieht Zeitgeschichtliche Forschungsstelle Ingolstadt (ZFI) im Zwielicht''], 22 December 2006</ref>
Some of the more active critics of the institution include the left-wing journalist [[Anton Maegerle]], who published his portrait of the ZFI in 1996.<ref>[http://www.bnr.de/content/kaempfer-fuer-eine-neue-zeitgeschichte Kämpfer für eine neue Zeitgeschichte] in Blick nach Rechts 29.05.1996</ref> Its publications are widely considered to be of [[Historical revisionism (negationism)|revisionist]] nature.<ref>[[Wolfgang Wippermann]]:''Verdiente Revisionisten. Alfred Schickel und die "Zeitgeschichtliche Forschungsstelle Ingolstadt (ZFI)"''. In: Johannes Klotz, Ulrich Schneider (eds.): ''Die selbstbewußte Nation und ihr Geschichtsbild.'' Köln 1997, {{ISBN|3-89438-137-X}}, pp. 78-95.</ref>
== Award program == {{Refimprove section|date=October 2010}} Die ZFI also awards the ''Dr. Walter-Eckhardt-Ehrengabe für Zeitgeschichtsforschung'' (“Dr. Walter Eckhardt Honorary Gift for Contemporary Historical Research”). Among the recipients in the preceding years were:
* Alfred Schickel (1986) * [[Joachim Hoffmann]] (1991) * Walter Post (1993) * [[Franz W. Seidler]] (1998) * [[Alfred-Maurice de Zayas]] (2001)
==Literature== * Andreas Angerstorfer, Annemarie Dengg: ''Rechte Strukturen in Bayern. Eine Dokumentation mit Schwerpunkt Oberbayern, Oberpfalz und Niederbayern.'' Second revised edition, Munich 2005 * [[Anton Maegerle]]: „Club der Revisionisten“. ''[[Blick nach Rechts]]'' Nr. 25, 11 December 2006. * Bernd Wagner: ''Handbuch Rechtsextremismus - Netzwerke, Parteien, Organisationen, Ideologiezentren, Medien'', Reinbek near Hamburg 1994
